name: Painting Science: Art + Science for Education
description: Can science be effectively communicated through art? Where do the two fields intersect, and how can they offer us new ways to interrogate existing knowledge? Join Ravi Jambhekar in an hands-on exploration of how visual media can bring scientific concepts to life. Through the lens of natural history painting, Jambhekar will take us on a journey that brings together science and art.

name: Bengaluru in Blue, Green and Grey: The Ecological and Environmental Dimensions of Blue-green Infrastructure
description:
How can rapid urbanisation, combined with biodiversity loss, water insecurity, and climate change, be mitigated through nature-based solutions? Cities, like Bengaluru, are prone to environmental stresses like water scarcity, pollution and heat stress. ‘Blue and Green spaces’ in the city can help address these issues but their ecological and hydrological functions must be better understood for resilience and effectiveness. Bengaluru, like many Indian cities, has both existing and emerging ‘blue and green spaces’ with various levels of protection from land use and land-cover change.

Join Jagdish Krishnaswamy in understanding the current and future linkages between Bengaluru’s blue, green and grey.

name: Paper and Play: Hands-on Mathematics
description:
Does Mathematics seem scary and difficult to you? Can it be fun?
In this workshop by K (Ravi) Subramaniam, play games, cut and fold paper and observe the patterns emerge from it. In the process, engage with the mathematics that we encounter during these activities.
Come experience fun with mathematics — the way a mathematician would.

name: Wearing skeletons and tasting with feet: Insects and Their Impact on Humanity
description:
Do you reach for repellant everytime you see an insect? Does the mere mention of insects make you shudder? Whether insects cause fear or fascination, this lecture is for you.
Learn about the first animals to start agriculture, use antibiotics and live in societies. With over a million species and being the most diverse group of animals on earth, these critters are not to be easily dismissed. Come listen to Divya Uma about the fascinating world of insects and how they wear their skeletons on the outside, breathe with holes in their bodies, taste with their feet and much more!

name: Small but Mighty: Engineered Nanoparticles in the Human Body
description:
Can we look at biology from the lens of materials science? How can materials on the nanoscale pose risks to health as well as potentially revolutionise cancer therapy?
Using everyday examples like cigarette smoke, sunscreen, air pollutants and wound dressings, Aahana Ganguly takes us on a journey through the multidisciplinary field of nanoparticles. She explores where nanoscience meets medicine with a particular focus on cancer therapy while also analysing the challenges that arise in their development. She also identifies gaps where young aspiring scientists can make their contributions.

name: Who Gets (or does not Get) to do Science, and Why: Feminist Perspectives
description:
Talent and hard work is enough to do science, right? Is this indeed the case?
Come look under the sociological microscope with Gita Chadha to understand how social and cultural privileges play into who really gets to do science. Listen to her shed light on the immense difficulties and struggles that one must face, particularly by those who belong to marginalised groups in society. She also explores possible explanations for why the culture and nature of science might be biassed in favour of some.
